results.title: Commonwealth Arts Festival
results.brief_description: A film record of the highlights from the Commonwealth Arts Festival held in Britain in 1965. For 17 days, in London, Cardiff, Liverpool and Glasgow, there were performances of music, drama, dancing, films and verse, as well as art exhibitions. More than 20 Commonwealth countries brought their finest talents and exhibits to Britain for the occasion.

results.title: Commonsense behind the wheel
results.brief_description: The film opens with a casualty case in a hospital after a traffic accident. Rules for safe driving are enumerated and explained with practical demonstrations. Shows the need for correct hand signals and also the disastrous effects of driving whilst under the influence of alcohol.

results.title: Commonsense afoot!
results.brief_description: Opens with a newspaper summary of the accident rate. Deals with the rules for pedestrian traffic, both on the footpath and on the road; the use of school crossings; the correct way of alighting from cars, trains, and buses; the advisability of walking against the traffic on country roads.

results.title: Commonsense a cycle
results.brief_description: Shows the hazard of riding a bicycle in heavy traffic. Shows how foolish riding habits result in accidents and makes an appeal to parents as well as children to see that bicycles are kept in good order and that young children know and obey traffic rules.

results.title: Common Threads : Stories from the Quilt
results.creator_credit: Jeffrey Friedman, Robert Epstein, Bill Couturie and Telling Pictures
results.brief_description: This Oscar winning film celebrates five individuals who have died from AIDS. Through interviews, photos, home movies and other remembrances, the portraits of these five people and their loved ones show how they came to terms with their loss by participating in the AIDS Memorial Quilt. The film also encapsulates the history of the AIDS epidemic as reported by the news media in the U.S. from 1981-89. Including an interview with writer Vito Russo. Narrated by Dustin Hoffman.

results.title: Common heart disorders and their causes
results.brief_description: The film first reviews the proper functioning of a healthy heart and circulatory system. It then studies common heart disorders giving the history, symptoms and effects of a typical case of childhood rheumatic fever; the assumed causes of hypertension and the effects of each of the conditions which may be caused by arteriosclerosis (hardening of the arteries). Correlated with “Textbook of healthful living” by Dr Harold S. Diehl.

results.title: Commitment
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country Education Project
results.brief_description: Jocelyn Terry leads a discussion with Laurie Clancy of La Trobe University and Colin Goodwin of the Phillip Institute, in aspects of commitment as revealed in Thomas Keneally’s book “Schindler’s Ark” and in Graham Greene’s book “The Power and the Glory”. Some provocative considerations emerge about the varieties of commitment, motivations for and consequences of commitment, as revealed in these texts.

results.title: Commercial sexual exploitation of children
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Bird, Gail Price and ECPAT Australia
results.brief_description: Discusses the global issue of commercial exploitation of children and the various forms this abuse can take, eg prostitution, slave-trade, pedophilia, internet pornography. Mentions some of the causes as being poverty, homelessness, consumerism, absence of child protection, cultural and traditional practices and a growing child sex tourist trade. Also talks about positive strategies that can be taken at all levels, local, regional, national and international. ECPAT is an international network of organisations committed to ending the commercial exploitation of children. Formed in 1991, ECPAT now reaches to over 50 countries globally and closely works with various government departments, such as Tourism and Child Welfare. Cast: Michael Brakensiek, Sarah Hill, Michael Williams, Afshin Nikousheresht. Narration: Patrick J. Bonello, Damian Nicholas.

results.title: Coming out under fire
results.creator_credit: Arthur E. Dong and Deepfocus Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the book of the same name by Allan Berube, who co-wrote the documentary, “Coming out under fire” interviews ten gays and lesbians who served in the military during the Second World War. Intercut with declassified military “education” films and newsreels, the interviews form a grave counterpoint to the campy, wholly ludicrious and sometimes painful stock footage where homosexuals were portrayed as darkly psychologically malevolent individuals. This entrenched homophobia resulted in anti-homosexual dragnets and entrapment schemes that caused great psychological distress to homosexuals within the military. The documentary is framed by the 1993 U.S. congressional hearings which resulted in the so-called “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy toward gays in the armed services, a policy which was calculated to please no-one and which was predicted to be a failure before it ever began, opening the gates once more on service-wide anti-homosexual entrapment schemes.
